instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello, 

This macbook came in today not booting , I plugged my amp amp meter and Device is charging normal pulling 20V 39W and 1.48 Amp  but if press power button , there s no boot , press caps lock key no light and no dim light on screen, I proceeded to open it to run an inspection and found some corrosion around the backlight IC and when I checked for short there was no short, so I cleaned it with a little brush and little bit of  99% alcohol , reinstall board for test still device is charging normal but no boot  no display n no light on Caps lock, I ran some diode mode reading measurements and found <SIGNAL>PPVCC_SO_CPU</SIGNAL>  is 0.00 .
Does that mean CPU is dead ?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Here s a picture of the corroded area that I found , everywhere else was neat.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Finding corrosion around backlight circuit means always bad news.

CPU coils have low readings as normal.
You should use ohm scale in this case.

Tell us which coils get voltage, apart of CPU ones.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I have another board here good working one , and I compare the readings , And Yes the CPU is Partially  shorted,  L7670 5V is present  L7690 3V3 is also there L7030  12V present, all the other coils are 0v

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post exact ohm resistance to ground on CPU coils for both boards.
If you get big difference, CPU is dead.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: To me CPU is dead  or  it needs reballing.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Reball a dead chip; how can help?
Dead you hear about massage of a wood foot?
